Abstract:

New Statistical and Deep learning emthods, in the wide public, are commonly linked to ‚Äúbig data‚Äù scenario. However, especially in healthcare, collecting and annotating large data sets can be very time-consuming and too expensive. In addition, because of the huge and strict regulation that envelops such personal and sensitive data, it‚Äôs uncommon also to find freely available datasets online. Such boundaries, leads the data professional with a very narrow portfolio of choices mostly when managing predictive models. The challenge deals both with modeling and pre-processing the data since a bad choice in one of these steps can deal with a sub-optimal result with the risk of low-quality decision-making. In addition, low data availability can affect also less complex models in survival analysis when studying a specific disease to discover new patterns to develop new care scenarios, then there is a low probability of finding additional data to compare and validate such phenomenon. Given the data challenge, the manuscript explores the phenomenon theoretically and empirically by conducting two main experiments considering classical statistical methods and deep learning solutions like transfer learning capable of solving tasks in cross-domain knowledge. The thesis underlines how these algorithms behave when dealing with fragmented, structured, and unstructured data created by healthcare systems. The work highlights that despite the scarcity of data available, embracing data science in healthcare can provide practical insights for physicians boosting healthcare quality and evidence-based medicine. what‚Äôs popped from the interview:
In May 2024 we had a huge interview in Padua with 2 medical doctors who just came back from a mission in Africa. The two young MDs did 6 months of residency in two different countries in the African continent. What they explained to us is that it doesn‚Äôt matter which kind of medical expertise you are doing there. There is a huge need, especially for women and children. Before taking action with the local population it‚Äôs essential to deal with their culture and then evaluate which kind of action and medical solution to implement.‚Äù

title: Artificial intelligence will improve your healthcare job routine
text:
AI and Medical journey
LLMs in medicine are nowadays super in hype. Or better, GenAI is super in hype. The last one is different from traditional AI in that it can generate content, such as summaries of text and answers to questions, rather than merely analyzing existing data. GenAI can definitively improve your work as healthcare professional since the goal is just to ‚Äúremoving the robot that is inside you to let you perform more human related task‚Äù. Hence the opportunity here of GenAI is just to manage exactly all the jobs that as healthcare professional you try to avoid every day to let you as much time as possible with patients. This since GenAI can empower your role, plus the patients to take a more active role in their healthcare. This since patients can use LLM-powered chatbots to interact with their EHR, prepare for appointments.
While challenges exist, the benefits of GenAI are too significant to ignore, and it may revolutionize care delivery by automating tasks, improving patient self-management, and enhancing job satisfaction.
By actively engaging in the development and implementation of GenAI, and adopting a balanced approach that prioritizes safety and responsibility, we can explore its potential to transform the way we deliver cardiovascular care and ultimately improve patient outcomes.
